subject: The Songs Are Heard Again
event: The Subterranean Press hardcover of our Jack Vance tribute anthology, SONGS OF THE DYING EARTH, is sold out in all editions (lettered, numbered, and trade). But if you missed your chance, don't despair. You can still read a baker's score of Dying Earth stories from twenty-one of today's leading fantasists... the Voyager hardcover has just been released in the UK. This will be one of the books that I will be signing in Ireland next month, at the events in Belfast and Dublin... but if you can't wait to read the stories, or happen to live someplace other than Ireland, you can snag at copy from Amazon UK or your favorite British online bookstore. The Amazon listing is at http://www.amazon.co.uk/Songs-Dying-Earth-Stories-honour/dp/0007277482/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1255117666&sr=8-1 SONGS OF THE DYING EARTH was co-edited by me and Gardner Dozois, and includes a preface by Jack Vance himself, an appreciation by Dean Koontz, and stories by Neil Gaiman, Dan Simmons, Howard Waldrop, Mike Resnick, Phyllis Eisenstein, Kage Baker, Paula Volsky, Walter Jon Williams, Liz Williams, Tad Williams, Byron Tetrick, Elizabeth Moon, Elizabeth Hand, Jeff Vandermeer, Terry Dowling, Matthew Hughes, John C. Wright, Glen Cook, Lucius Shepard, Tanith Lee, Robert Silverberg, and yours truly. You're not likely to find a lineup to match that in any other anthology. Reviews have been very gratifying: http://thewertzone.blogspot.com/2009/07/songs-of-dying-earth-edited-by-george.html http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6664389.html?industryid=47120 http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&ie=UTF-8&q=Songs+of+the+Dying+Earth+review+Martin+Vance+Dozois&start=10&sa=N http://www.sfsite.com/09b/de304.htm So come join us on the Dying Earth to pay homage to the genius of Jack Vance.

comments.article:
I've just finished reading the Subterranean edition. Beautiful production values (but for some notable typos that slipped through the cracks, I admit), but more importantly, some really wonderful stories. I particularly took pleasure in the afterwords from the authors following their stories, showing how each and every one of them came to admire Vance's work (Howard Waldrop's was the most moving, in my mind).

Dan Simmons wrote the story which I think is probably my favorite, but really, it's an embarrassment of riches. And leave it to you to capture the flavor of Vance's blackest humor; Molloqos the Melancholy, the toad-like Chimwazzle, and Lirianne with her razor sharp Tickle-Me-Sweet fit right into the setting.

The first time I came across the Dying Earth, it was through "Mazirian the Magician" when I was somewhere in 7th-8th grade. It was collected in Asimov's, Greenberg's, and Waugh's anthology series, Magical Worlds. I remember the cover, which was my first exposure to Kinuko Kraft, too. All the stories were supposed to feature wizards, and I still remember reading some of these stories quite vividly: Le Guin's heartbreaking beautiful "Semley's Necklace" (part of her Ekumen setting, but I knew nothing about that then), REH's dark Conan adventure "The People of the Black Circle", Larry Niven's "What Good is a Glass Dagger?"...

But Mazirian and the Dying Earth beat them all for magic and wonder. Of course, I never could find the Dying Earth novels in the local libraries I had access to right then, nor in the bookstores. It took a number of years to rediscover Vance, which I did when you reminded me of him in a very early e-mail. You explained the origins of the Vance name in the series, and that triggered a memory, and next thing I knew I was ordering the book through the Internet.

So thanks for that (though the shelves do groan under the collection of Vance books I've amassed since then), and for this book (which'll sit near the rest, to keep them company).
And it is awesome!  Highest possible recommendation.

I'm serious, you are going to bankrupt me! In a detox from aSoI&F I started another popular fantasy series. Not WoT, though his comments on aGoT was what encouraged me to pick it up and I couldn't be more grateful that I did. Now wrapping up this other series, (whose tv adaptation is awful...should be called Legend of the Suck) I went to the bookstore this weekend for a new fix. I picked up Hunter's Run, Fevre Dream and Dreamsongs vol 2 (which I got on sale in hardcover...I wasn't aware there was a vol 1)
Aside from that I've neen checking out authors you've recommended on your page. You totally hit the nail on the head with Jacqueline Carey's The Sundering novels. Though you didn't mention any of the Kushiel novels, I picked up the first part.
Until I can get my next fix of what you got cooking I've been enjoying getting a glimpse of what you enjoy and I appreciate the new worlds you've opened for me. I will of course probably be needing to get a second job to support this habit. Your like a drug dealer! Evertime I check your blog it's some other new treat your dangling to inspire a case of the shakes.
Though I try my best to hide it from my girlfriend, I know she'd have a few choice words about your influence on me. My wallet & gf might not feel the same, but keep pouring the fuel on the fire my man!

comments.article: Thank you so much for helping bring "Songs" into being. I've loved the Dying Earth ever since I first read "Turjan of Miir" as a child. That story sat in the back of my unconscious mind for years, until as an adult I rediscovered it. I devoured Tales of the Dying Earth in two days. I continued on to most of Vance's other work, but was always disappointed that none of it was quite the Dying Earth. There was no more of that to read. But now there is, thanks to you and your collaborators. Thank you.
So Dying Earth is the best place to start reading Jack Vance?

It's certainly one of the best introductions to his work. Other good starting places are his Demon Princes series, which is science fiction, or Subterranean Press's recent collection The Jack Vance Treasury
It's great to see the UK version looking so good (;

As I read about Jack Vance and his work, as well as the tributes directed towards him, especially those collected in "Songs Of The Dying Earth", I knew I must have a copy of the book. Since in North America a new edition of the book is far away from release, I got my hands on copy of the UK version (from Amazon UK), which is outstanding, I simply loved the introduction and foreword.

It was a bit pricey, what with the conversion from British pounds, and the shipping and handling, but definitely well worth it. Harper/Voyager, did a great job. I really like the cover, it is so simple and poignant, none of the childish covers we sometimes get in the US or Canada.

You simply cannot go wrong with any book that has contributions from George RR Martin and Neil Gaiman, plus the bevy of other stellar authors included in the compilation.

Now if I can only get my lazy ass in gear and actually read the book...what can I say for the past year or so I have been in the middle or re-reading Jordan's "The Wheel Of Time", with ocassional breaks in which I read other books (Jose Saramago's "Blindness", Cormack McCarthy's "The Road", Phillip K. Dick's "A Scanner Darkly" and William Gibson's "Spook Country" amongst them). But since I am halfway through, and Brian Sanderson is moving towards the final books of the series, I will do my utmost to devour "Songs Of The Dying Earth". Not to mention, with a lot of shame, that I yet have to get to "A Song Of Ice and Fire"...I will say no more, because George RR Martin will smithe me with thunderous fury and righteouss anger...
